title: Fugitive Law approved in Indiana
content: Governor Wright's approval of this law showed the strong support which both he and state of Indiana had for the Union.  In his message on Jan 4th, 1851 he eloquently summed up his feelings on the matter, Â“There is no safety for property or life except in the absolute supremacy of the law: no higher duty of the citizen than to maintain by word and deed, that supremacy, as we value the heritage, rich beyond all price, purchased, not with silver or gold, but with life's blood of the good and brave;;Let us bear in mind that the first public act of disobedience to the law is the first fatal step on the downward road to anarchy.' (Richmond Whig)<br />In other parts of the country such as Massachusetts the Fugitive Slave Act was being followed on the order of the President and the Federal Government.  Abolitionists warned blacks of police officers and watchmen who had been ordered by the mayor of Boston to kidnap fugitive slaves.

data: Pauline Maier, Merritt Roe Smith, Alexander Keyssar, and Daniel Kevles
